dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 279-point jump for the Dow, huh? I feel like we're on a rollercoaster this week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A two hundred seventy nine-point jump for the Dow, huh? I feel like we're on a rollercoaster this week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow dropped 879 points, or 3.1%, while the S&P 500 lost 3% and the Nasdaq Composite lost 2.8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And the Nasdaq up almost 4%—investors are really diving back into tech stocks with both feet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And the Nasdaq up almost four percent-investors are really diving back into tech stocks with both feet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow dropped 879 points, or 3.1%, while the S&P 500 lost 3% and the Nasdaq Composite lost 2.8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's all tied to that WHO announcement about coronavirus containment, which is… uh, pretty optimistic, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's all tied to that W H O announcement about coronavirus containment, which is... uh, pretty optimistic, honestly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got Peter Navarro saying the exact opposite on Fox Business—calling it an economic catastrophe. Which one is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got Peter Navarro saying the exact opposite on Fox Business-calling it an economic catastrophe. Which one is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And then there's Larry Kudlow in The Wall Street Journal downplaying the whole thing, saying markets are actually too optimistic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And then there's Larry Kudlow in The Wall Street Journal downplaying the whole thing, saying markets are actually too optimistic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: National Economic Council director Larry Kudlow had a more optimistic view, telling CNBCs Kelly Evans that the coronavirus has been contained in the United States and that the outbreak is not likely to be an economic tragedy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like whiplash trying to keep up. Even Treasury yields are surging after the curve flattened Monday—so much jargon, but it matters.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like whiplash trying to keep up. Even Treasury yields are surging after the curve flattened Monday-so much jargon, but it matters.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 10-year U.S. Treasury yields hit a record low on Tuesday after the yield curvea measure of the difference between 3-month and 10-year bond yields that is widely used as a recession indicatorinverted on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And U.S. futures dropped overnight, which makes Tuesday's rally even more surprising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And U.S. futures dropped overnight, which makes Tuesday's rally even more surprising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. futures had rallied slightly overnight following Mondays losses, seemingly pointing to a Tuesday rebound, but stocks largely remained in the red during the day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But hey, The New York Times piece says even with gains like this, experts say don't get too comfortable—sell the highs, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But hey, The New York Times piece says even with gains like this, experts say don't get too comfortable-sell the highs, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even with these major losses, experts say you shouldnt panic yet. One silver lining? Investors typically buy the dip following big drops.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Classic advice. Though I gotta say, after a 2% S&P climb, it's hard not to feel a little hopeful.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Classic advice. Though I gotta say, after a two percent S&P climb, it's hard not to feel a little hopeful.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow dropped 879 points, or 3.1%, while the S&P 500 lost 3% and the Nasdaq Composite lost 2.8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but then you remember Navarro's warning and that $40 billion question about Trump's company if he wins…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but then you remember Navarro's warning and that forty dollars billion question about Trump's company if he wins...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If Bloomberg Wins, Heres Who Might Pay The Estimated $60 Billion For His Company

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh man, don't get me started. Let's just enjoy the green while it lasts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh man, don't get me started. Let's just enjoy the green while it lasts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Deal. Until the next headline flips everything upside down again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Deal. Until the next headline flips everything upside down again.

HostA: Yeah, and it’s all tied to that WHO announcement about coronavirus containment, which is… uh, pretty optimistic, honestly.
HostB: But then you’ve got Peter Navarro saying the exact opposite on Fox Business—calling it an economic catastrophe. Which one is it?
HostA: Exactly! And then there’s Larry Kudlow in The Wall Street Journal downplaying the whole thing, saying markets are actually too optimistic.
HostB: It’s like whiplash trying to keep up. Even Treasury yields are surging after the curve flattened Monday—so much jargon, but it matters.
HostA: For sure. And U.S. futures dropped overnight, which makes Tuesday’s rally even more surprising.
HostB: But hey, The New York Times piece says even with gains like this, experts say don’t get too comfortable—sell the highs, apparently.
HostA: Classic advice. Though I gotta say, after a 2% S&P climb, it’s hard not to feel a little hopeful.
HostB: True, but then you remember Navarro’s warning and that $40 billion question about Trump’s company if he wins…
HostA: Oh man, don’t get me started. Let’s just enjoy the green while it lasts.
